TranscripTools 0.1.0

Perform and Plot PCA with Customizable Aesthetics

pcafun.Rd

This function performs Principal Component Analysis (PCA) on a count matrix and generates a biplot using PCAtools. It streamlines the workflow—especially for pathway-specific PCAs—by performing the analysis and plotting in one step.

Usage

pcafun(
  counts,
  metadata,
  title,
  colby = "samples",
  shapekey = NULL,
  showLoadings = TRUE
)

Arguments

counts

A numeric matrix or data frame containing count data (e.g., TMM or TPM values) with rows as features (e.g., genes) and columns as samples.

metadata

A data frame containing sample metadata. The row names of metadata should correspond to the column names of counts.

title

A character string for the PCA plot title.

colby

A character string specifying the column name in metadata used to color the samples in the PCA plot. Default is "samples".

shapekey

An optional character string specifying the column name in metadata used to shape the points in the PCA plot. Default is NULL, meaning no special grouping by shape.

showLoadings

A logical value indicating whether to display the loadings on the PCA biplot. Default is TRUE.

Value

A ggplot object representing the PCA biplot.

Details

This function leverages PCAtools::pca to compute the principal components and PCAtools::biplot to create the biplot. By providing customizable parameters for both color and shape aesthetics (via colby and shapekey), along with an option to toggle the display of loadings, this function enables users to quickly generate tailored PCA visualizations without manually calculating PCA and then plotting it separately.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Assume counts is your count matrix and metadata contains corresponding sample information:
pca_plot <- pcafun(counts, metadata, title = "Pathway-Specific PCA",
                   colby = "treatment", shapekey = "batch", showLoadings = FALSE)
} # }
